body.p: Mary Russell Mitford submitted Charles the First, An Historial Tragedy, in Five Acts to the Examiner of Plays, George Colman the Younger, for review in 1825. The play was refused a license at that time, and so did not reach the stage until its production at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. London publisher John Duncombe and Co. produced the first printed edition in 1834. Philadelphia publishers Carey & Hart, Hogan & Thompson, and W. Marshall and Co., published an American edition the following year, in 1835, as part of the series Alexander's Modern Acting Drama: Consisting of the Most Popular Plays Produced at the Philadelphia Theatres and Elsewhere. The play was also published in the 1880s by J. Dicks in the cheap reprint series Dicks' Standard Plays. The play was collected in 1841 by Philadelphia publisher James Crissy in The Works of Mary Russell Mitford: Prose and Verse. In 1854, the play was also included an authorized collection, The Dramatic Works of Mary Russell Mitford by London publisher Hurst and Blackett.

In the 1830s, before publishing the full-length play, Mitfordpublished several selections from her tragedy in literary annuals, including the Forget Me Not (1830 and 1831), the Royal Lady's Magazine (1832) and the Metropolitan Magazine (1832). An excerpt from the play was also included in the 1889 McGuffey's High School and Literary Reader as "The Trial of Charles the First": 230-237.

bibl.title: The Metropolitan
bibl.note: A London monthly originally titled The Metropolitan: A Monthly Journal of Literature, Science, and the Fine Arts. After 1833 it was retitled The Metropolitan Magazine. The periodical was founded by Thomas Campbell and edited by Campbell, Cyrus Redding, and Frederick Marryat (after 1832). Mitford published in this monthly in 1832.
